RELEASE: Kansas Tax Cuts: Lessons for NH Offers Legislators Context for Considering  Proposed Business Tax Cuts http://t.co/t4nHzYnI0g
NH should invest in schools, roads, and services essential to ensuring a strong economy and shared prosperity for all in the Granite State
Business tax cuts will make it harder to maintain our roads, educate our children, and provide health, safety, and other public services.
NH’s proposed business tax changes would drain more than $20M from FY16-17 budget, more than $100M from future budgets starting in FY 20-21
As Kansas experience shows: tax cuts that drain state resources have far reaching impacts for families, communities, and state economies
Without a sustainable rev structure to support investments in schools + infrastructure, KS is falling behind while neighbors move ahead
Today Kansas lags the region – and the nation – in economic growth rate. Private sector employment has declined since tax cuts.
Tax cuts in Kansas are having wide-reaching impact on state’s ability to expand its economy and to maintain essential services
B/w 2012-2013, 67 Kansas counties enacted property tax increases to offset the added cost of downshifted responsibilities
Efforts to close KS budget gap increased strain on local governments, forced many to raise property taxes to fund basic services
Kansas revenue shortfall is jeopardizing funding for education, roads and bridges, and other components essential to a strong economy
After 3 years, 2 credit downgrades, multiple rounds of budget cuts, and 2 new tax increases, Kansas remains in a perpetual budget crisis
Enacted in 2012, the 1st full year of tax cuts in Kansas resulted in greater revenue loss than the 3 years of the Great Recession combined
Much like NH’s proposed tax cuts, KS tax cuts were promoted as necessary to help businesses and increase economic growth.
Speakers: Kansas Center for Economic Growth Exec Dir Annie McKay + Senior Fellow Duane Goossen, frmr KS state budget director @ksprosperity
Kansas Tax Cuts: Lessons for New Hampshire is underway. We’ll share insights and highlights from the event.
Kansas Tax Cuts: Lessons for New Hampshire begins at noon. We’ll share insights and highlights from the event.

RELEASE: National State-Tax Expert Mazerov Outlines Why Business Tax Cuts Will Not Produce Economic Growth for NH http://t.co/9GK44ZZVTL
Mazerov: preserving high quality state and local services, esp education and infrastructure, should be the primary economic growth strategy
Mazerov: across the board cuts in business tax rates to boost economic growth is a wasteful inefficient way to achieve the goal
Mazerov: Most NE states rank above NH for investment in k-12 education
Mazerov: High quality services attract the "creative class" -- want good schools, vibrant  communities, high quality of life
Mazerov: considerable evidence that high quality public services enhance state economic performance
Mazerov: Impact of tax cuts in Ohio 2005 - 2015, no net increase in non-farm employment, while national average increased by 5.8%
Mazerov: Tax cuts do not pay for themselves.
Mazerov: “State level economic growth is not closely tied to state level tax policy,” conclusion of new Gale/Krupkin/Reuben stidy
Mazerov: what really drives economic growth is a state's ability to support business needs
Mazerov: Tax cuts won’t attract entrepreneurs, they start businesses where they have relationships and know there are market gaps
Mazerov: Business investment responds to demand for product, not small cut in tax expense or marginal rate
Mazerov:  A corporate tax cut at state level may increase fed tax liability; up to 1/3 of tax cut may go to federal gov’t, not business
Mazerov: To extent state/local tax matters to business, will compare total tax liability, not just one tax.
Gupta/Hofman study: “State policy makers should think carefully about using corp tax code as means to stimulate econ growth.”
Mazerov: NH ranks 7th Best in US on overall Tax Fnd 2015 State Business Tax Climate Index. (48th ranking is sub-index for corp tax policy.)
We’ll share insights from @CenterOnBudget Mazerov presentation, which outlines what the research says about economic growth and tax cuts
At noon @CenterOnBudget state tax policy expert Michael Mazerov will review the relationship b/w state business taxes + economic performance
